objectives: Use prepositions of place and movement

sections.text: When you want to go somewhere new, you need to know some special words to ask for or give directions. These words tell you where to go. They help you find your way, like 'left', 'right', and 'straight'.
usage_examples: Go straight down this road.
Turn left at the next street.
The shop is on your right side.
Please turn right at the crossroads.
Walk along the river bank.
Go towards the big banyan tree.
The well is next to the school.
The post office is opposite the bank.
My house is behind the temple.
The market is in front of the bus stand.
Turn left at the corner.
Cross the small bridge over the canal.
Go straight until you see the big field.
The health center is on the right side.
Take the path that goes to the left.

table.title: Basic Direction Words
rows: The school is on your right.
The well is near my house.

sections.text: Prepositions are small words that tell us the position or movement of things. When giving directions, they are very helpful. Words like 'at', 'on', 'in', 'near', 'across', 'through' help make your directions clear.

examples.label: At
examples.value: వద్ద (e.g., at the school, at the corner)

examples.label: On
examples.value: మీద (e.g., on the right, on the road)

examples.label: In
examples.value: లో (e.g., in the village, in front of the building)

examples.label: In front of
examples.value: ముందు (e.g., in front of the house)

usage_examples: The meeting is at the school.
The shop is on the main road.
You will find it in the middle of the village.
The bus stand is near the temple.
Walk across the bridge.
Go through the small lane.
We need to go to the market.
The health center is far from here.

My house is behind the post office.
The police station is in front of the bank.
Walk along the river for a bit.
Go over the small hill.

sections.text: When you give directions, it's helpful to mention known places, called 'landmarks'. These are places everyone knows, like a big temple, a school, or a main market. Also, tell people about the 'distance' (how far it is) and 'time' (how long it takes to reach there).
usage_examples: Go straight until you reach the big banyan tree.
The health center is near the village temple.
The shop is opposite the primary school.
Walk about 200 meters from here.
It's a 5 minutes walk to the market.
The bus stand is near the old well.
The new bank is not far from here.
It's about 10 minutes by cycle to the government hospital.
You will see the police station on your left after the river bridge.
The water tank is a good landmark to find the way.
The market is a little far from the main road.
The meeting hall is just nearby the school.
It's around one kilometer from this point.
It will take some time to reach the district office.
Walk past the big field, then you will see it.

subtopics.title: Polite Questions to Ask for Directions

sections.text: When you ask someone for directions, always be polite. Start with phrases like 'Excuse me' or 'Could you please'. This shows respect and makes people more willing to help you.

examples.label: Common 2

sections.text: When you give directions, tell people step by step. Use simple commands and mention landmarks clearly. Imagine you are walking with them in your mind and telling them what to do at each turn or important spot.

sections.text: When giving directions, also be polite and helpful. You can start by saying 'Sure,' or 'Yes, I can help you.' End by saying 'You're welcome' or 'No problem' after they thank you.

examples.label: Confirm willingness
examples.value: Yes, I can help you with that.

examples.label: Offering more help
examples.value: If you get lost, you can ask someone else.

examples.label: Clear phrasing
examples.value: So, first left, then straight, then right.

examples.label: Simple confirmation
examples.value: Yes, you are on the right path.

subtopics.title: Sample Conversation: To the Post Office

sections.text: Read this conversation where someone asks for and gets directions to a common place like a post office in a village setting.
usage_examples:
Ramesh: Excuse me, uncle. Can you tell me how to reach the post office?
Uncle: Yes, beta. It's not far from here. First, go straight down this road. You will see the big peepal tree after about 50 meters.
Ramesh: Okay, the peepal tree.
Uncle: Yes. From there, take a left turn. Walk for about 100 meters, and you will see the primary school on your right side.
Ramesh: The primary school, on the right.
Uncle: Correct. The post office is just opposite the school. You can't miss it.
Ramesh: Thank you very much for your help, uncle!
Uncle: You're welcome, beta. Have a good day.

subtopics.title: Sample Conversation: To the Health Center

sections.text: Here's another example of asking for directions to a health center. Notice the details given about landmarks and distance.
usage_examples:
Lady: Excuse me, young man. I am new here. How do I get to the health center?
Boy: Good morning, madam. The health center is a little far, but I can guide you. From here, walk straight past the village market. Keep walking until you reach the small bridge over the stream.
Lady: The bridge, okay.
Boy: After crossing the bridge, you will see a small lane going to your right. Take that lane. Walk through that lane for about 3 minutes. The health center will be the big white building at the end of the lane, on your left.
Lady: Thank you so much for the clear directions. Is it about a 15-minute walk?
Boy: Yes, madam, approximately 15 minutes walk. Or 5 minutes by cycle. Hope you find it easily.
Lady: Thank you again, God bless you.

subtopics.title: Role-Play Activity: Giving and Asking for Directions

sections.text:
Let's practice! Work with a partner. One person will ask for directions, and the other will give directions. You can use the map of your school or imagine your village for this.

Scenario 1 (School):
*   Student 1: You are new to the school. Ask for directions to the Principal's office.
*   Student 2: You know the school well. Give directions from the classroom to the Principal's office.

Scenario 2 (Village):
*   Student 1: You are a visitor looking for the nearest well/pond.
*   Student 2: You are a villager. Give directions from the main road to the well/pond.

Remember to use polite language, clear direction words, and mention landmarks. You can also talk about distance and time.
usage_examples:
Student 1: Excuse me, can you tell me how to reach the Principal's office?
Student 2: Yes, go straight down this corridor, then turn right at the library. His office is next to the staff room.
Student 1: Is it far from here?
Student 2: No, it's a short walk, maybe two minutes.
Student 1: Thank you very much.
Student 2: You're welcome.
Student 1: Excuse me, where is the nearest well?
Student 2: From here, walk straight past the temple. Then turn left at the mango tree. The well is on your right side.
Student 1: How far is it?
Student 2: About a five-minute walk. It's not far.
Student 1: Thank you for your help.
Student 2: No problem.
